properties.name: Alabama
properties.Updated Notes: Cross check with field implementation. Alabama wasn't famous for its advance math education system. If the public universites still require Alg I, Geo and Alg II, how are the teachers incorporating DS?
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Alabama has some standards on statistics and data analysis in their K-12 framework, including an innovative Geometry with Data Analysis course. However, most of the aforementioned standards and courses are not mandatory, indicating that only a small portion of students would benefit from them. We suggest including more data science standards in the mandatory math curricula.
properties.Reasoning: Good stats and data analysis units in math standards; standards are K-12; use of tech; data analysis in some math elective
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): More obvious/thorough data analysis in viable math electives
properties.Questions: How long are stats/data science units?
Involve vizualizing data, drawing conclusions from data, making data-based decision, "quantitative literacy" (stats + data science); suggests using technology for data analysis
properties.Standards related to data science: Required sequence (2019) of high school math incorporates data analysis, stats, and probability; basic data collection and analysis at lower levels
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Incorporated into traditional math sequence (note sequence is geo, alg I, alg II)
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: State decided to add more stats/data analysis
properties.Levels of instruction: K-8 emphasises familiarity with data, sampling, and very basic stats; "quantitative literacy" and most of the detailed data science is high school level
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 4 years math required, specifies 3 courses (Algebra I, Geo, Alg II) with the 4th being a choice
Additional 4th course could be "Mathematical Modeling" which has some data analysis/math applications in it
properties.Availability/Access: Statewide requirements adopted 2019; prior to that ranked very low in math education, effect of new standards undetermined as of now. CS required in high schools by 2022-2023 school year
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: Requires 3 units including Alg I, Alg II, and Geo/Calc/Trig; recommends computer literacy as additional course

properties.name: Alaska
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Alaska has very basic statistics standards and limited data analysis standards, with most of them taught in middle school. We suggest incorporting those standards into high school years and creating more standards related to data science and data literacy.
properties.Reasoning: Very basic stats standards that are vague; little bit of data interpretation in math, comp sci; decent stats in middle school
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State plan, put in math classes
properties.Standards related to data science: Data and Analysis component of comp sci courses, involving computational tools, spreadsheets, applications to real world data sets, etc; not terribly specific
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Focus on comp sci
properties.Levels of instruction: Scaling standards for each grade up to high school, then two standards for high school
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 3 units of math required, doesn't specify certain courses/sequence, but many traditional concepts are required under educational standards
Computer science does not appear to be counted as math credit (elective or technical education), so data science won't count towards math requirement
properties.Availability/Access: Available at high school level in larger district at least, but fairly low participation rates (due to elective status?)
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: Varies based school, but Fairbanks suggest 3/4 years of "college prep" math

properties.name: Arizona
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Arizona has some standards related to statistics in the Computer Science framework, but the state has very few standards on data science. We suggest developing more robust standards regarding quantitative analysis & visualization and data science, especially in the math curricula.
properties.Reasoning: Math standards cover some stats, but not much data analysis; some in comp sci
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): More robust standards covering data analysis, not just basic stats
Math standards for Algebra II contain some instruction on data interpretation
properties.Standards related to data science: Computer science standards from 2018 contain a bit of instruction on interpreting and using data to support claims
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: "Business Operations" includes using spreadsheets to analyze data
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Part of comp sci and math classes
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Little focus
properties.Levels of instruction: Relevant data literacy aspects of comp sci are mostly middle school, and aspects of math curriculum are for high school
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 4 units of math required, including Alg I, Geo, Alg II, and a fourth course
It appears comp sci can substitute for the Alg II credit in some cases, and can also count as the 4th math credit
properties.Availability/Access: Standards adopted statewide; previously comp sci was not widely taught, unclear if that has changed
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 4 years math

properties.name: Arkansas
properties.Updated Notes: CTE sequence spotlighted + teacher PD. No other plans to add to K-12 mathematics at this time though.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Arkansas has good statistics and data analysis standards in their K-12 framework. Additionally, the Arkansas Department of Education has created an innovative three-course sequence on data science. Several districts have begun to implement the sequence, and the state has dedicated funding for the professional development of teachers. However, the sequence is an elective option. We suggest expanding access to the sequence and developing more data science standards in the mandatory math curricula.
properties.Reasoning: Math standards cover some stats, potential electives in math and comp sci cover data science but are either transitional courses or not widely taken
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): More robust standards covering data analysis, not just basic stats; also math electives that are more accessible. Could improve if math electives are widely taken
"Quantitative Literacy" class involves the application of math to real life (personal and business finance), but included some material on data and drawing conclusions; but transitional course
properties.Standards related to data science: As of 2021-2022 school year, have new "data science" courses for high school under comp sci, but seem fairly focused on computers--data in relation to computers, algorithms, impact of computers, etc
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Arkansas has developed a new three-course sequence for data science, of which districts around the state can now choose to adopt.
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Data science  and Quantitative Literacy are both separate, likely taken senior years after Alg II or potentially as a substitute for Alg II
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Focus on comp sci at state level
properties.Levels of instruction: High school, some stats/data analysis in comp sci and math
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 4 courses of math required, including Alg I and Geo, and for SmartCore (which they want students to do) Alg II and another course such as comp sci
Comp sci not required, but counts for math credit
properties.Availability/Access: Comp sci standards new this year
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 4 years, including Alg I, Geo, Alg II, and a fourth year beyond Alg II or comp sci

properties.name: California
properties.Updated Notes: Framework adoption is tentative, though robustly includes DS. No resources for instruction
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): California has an excellent focus on data science in their proposed mathematics framework, including data science standards that extend from high school into middle school. The state also included data-related content in elementary school math standards. Multiple data science electives in high school have also been approved by the University of California A-G requirements. However, aside from the forthcoming framework, the state has yet to make additional resources available for teacher training or instruction support. We look forward to seeing the concrete application of the new framework in classrooms.
properties.Reasoning: Math standards have some focus on data; excellent focus on data science in new math framework, but nothing concrete from it yet (and potential delays due to controversial aspects) so don't get full credit
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): If data science focus translates to concrete improvements, could easily move to B/A
properties.Questions: How far along is this initiative/how much credit do they get?
Program in LA for IDS curriculum (RISC involvement). Recent guidance emphasizes data science as a math course in high school,
properties.Standards related to data science: New comp sci standards (2018) have some material on vizualizing/analyzing data; math curriculum includes basic stats/probability instruction
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Teaches use of spreadsheets in a CTE elective.
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Incorporated into math/comp sci curriculum, except for IDS program
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Focus on comp sci at state level
properties.Levels of instruction: High school, stats in middle school
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 2 years of math required, including Alg I--therefore fairly flexible but no incentive to take certain classes
Data science counts for math credit, seems to be separate pathway?
properties.Availability/Access: IDS curriculum in LA school district only, computer science being adopted statewide. Guidance likely too new to have had effect yet, also what is RISC's position on equity/loss of accelerated options also emphasized by the guidance?
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 3 years that include algebra and geo content; the more selective schools will probably expect more rigorous coursework

properties.name: Colorado
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Colorado has comprehensive math standards, but those standards have a limited scope regarding data science. We suggest expanding and clarifying the aspects of the math standards that cover data science and applied statistics and incorporating such standards into earlier grades.
properties.Reasoning: Math standards show some promise, but aren't thorough enough to make the D grade; little bit in comp sci but not widely taken
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State plan, expand and clarify math standards covering data science and stats; more in earlier grades
Some general stats/probability incorporated into math curriculum
properties.Standards related to data science: Computational thinking component of comp sci standards covers data vizualization and interpretation, as well as real-world applications
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Some coding, basic business data analysis instruction
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Within comp sci and math classes
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: little focus; some funding for comp sci programs
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: No state-wide graduation requirements based on classes; individual districts have different requirements but likely require some standard math classes
properties.Availability/Access: Comp sci standards and classes are optional offerings in high school, and particpation appears low
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 4 years math, including 2 Alg, 1 Geo, and another "college prep"

properties.name: Connecticut
properties.Updated Notes: APRIL CANN YOU REVIEW BASED ON YOUR CONVERSATION WITH ELIZABETH: Check with state lead, Elizabeth. I know they are quite eager to work with us to figure out ways to incorporate data science. +1 ZD, should be higher, I know they are doing work on standards I believe.
properties.Changes: Moved it up to C. Elizabeth and her team are in the process of developing data science / computational thinking courses.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Connecticut has solid standards regarding data analysis, but such standards are mostly embedded in the computer science courses, which are not taken as widely as math. We suggest exploring ways to expand students' access to data science education - either by making computer science mandatory or incorporating data science standards into the math framework.
properties.Reasoning: Good data analysis standards but in comp sci for middle and high school (start early); common core math standards not very robust
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): Make comp sci mandatory or move data analysis elsewhere;
properties.Questions: I gave credit for optional comp sci; should we? Credit for allowing more flexibility in graduation?
Uses Common Core for math, has section on interpreting data
properties.Standards related to data science: Section on data analysis, vizualization, and interpretation in comp sci standards
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Little bit of data analysis in business instruction, also some coding/comp sci
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Comp sci appears to be a focus; large bill passed last year
properties.Levels of instruction: bill applies to K-12; data analysis aspects are mostly middle and high school
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: Currently requires 3 math credits; class of 2023 changes to 9 credits for STEM courses
Class of 2023 standards allow for much more flexibility in terms of what courses can be taken to count towards graduation
properties.Availability/Access: Comp sci required in high school now, standards state-wide
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: Alg I, Alg II, Geo
properties.Other notes: Project at UConn designed to add a unit on "computational thinking" to high school bio classes

properties.name: Delaware
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Delaware has very basic statistics standards and limited standards regarding data science. We suggest expanding and clarifying math standards to cover data science and applied statistics.
properties.Reasoning: Straightforward: some comp sci and math standards, no state focus
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State plan; incorporate data analysis standards into classes
Uses Common Core for math, section in high school on interpreting data
properties.Standards related to data science: Follows CSTA K-12 standards, has limited instruction on data literacy/analysis
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Marketing contains data analytics, computer science program
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Incorporated a little into other classes
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: little focus
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 4 credits of math required, including Geo, Alg I, and Alg II
Comp sci doesn't appear to count towards a math requirement
properties.Availability/Access: Comp sci courses seem fairly available but only as electives
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 3 years of math, recommends 4

properties.name: District of Columbia
properties.Updated Notes: Increased grade given teacher PD pilot. We should recnogize at least a C.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): The District of Columbia adopts Common Core math standards, which include very limited standards regarding data science. However, DC has some standards related to data science in the computer science framework. Additionally, DC Public Schools is piltoing a professional development program for mathematics educators in partnership with America University to bring data science courses to the district in future school years. We suggest expanding data analysis in math, and potentially making data science education mandatory.
properties.Reasoning: CC standards; bit of data analysis in comp sci
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State-level plan; add more standards into math, comp sci, other classes
Uses common core for math, section in high school on interpreting data, not very detailed/practical
properties.Standards related to data science: Comp sci standards (recommended, not city-made) used have data analysis section, but vague
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Some data analysis in the business part of CTE
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Doesn't seem to be much focus on comp sci or math, but also much smaller scale (have fairly rigorous standards but do care a lot about education, require a lot of community service)
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 4 years of math, including Alg I, Geo, Alg II
properties.Availability/Access: comp sci not widespread

properties.name: Florida
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Florida has an optional course with a solid unit on data analysis. However, the state's standards for math do not cover much beyond basic statistics. We suggest developing more data science standards and potentially making the aforementioned course more accessible to students.
properties.Reasoning: Does have optional course with solid unit on data analysis, but mandatory standards for math don't cover very much beyond a little bit of stats for high school
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): Extend data analysis aspects of math elective into madatory standards; potentially make elective course more appealing to advanced students (currently appears as course for those not interested in higher level math)
Math has standard stats/probability aspects, is also class called "mathematics for Data and Financial Literacy" which involves evaluating data and making predictions
properties.Standards related to data science: Comp sci standards have section on modeling and simulation that includes some data analysis--not major focus though
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Courses on comp sci, databases
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: In comp sci, sort of own data literacy class (w/ heavy emphasis on practicality)
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Comp sci has funding/initiative at state level
properties.Levels of instruction: standards for K-12, relevant data analysis found in high school section
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 4 math credits required, including Alg I and Geo. Comp sci can sub for one of those.
properties.Availability/Access: Standards state-wide, but as of 2018 only 33% of schools offer comp sci,
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 4 years including Alg I, Alg II, Geo

We suggest exploring ways to expand students' access to data science education - either by making computer science mandatory or incorporating data science standards into the math framework.

Standard data analysis/stats part of math standards,

properties.name: Illinois
properties.Updated Notes: New Illinois CS requirement is quite sweeping. Not math integration yet, but wanted to recognize.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Illinois adopts Common Core math standards, which has limited standards regarding data science and applied statistics. We suggest developing data analysis standards in the math framework, and/or launching pilot data science electives in selected high schools. Illinois's new requirement for all high schools to offer computer science courses by the 2023-24 school year will likely boost enrollment in Computer Science and students' familiarity with data science. However, this coursework will not be required of all students.
properties.Reasoning: Same common core math standards (ok, not great); little else
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): Incorporate data analysis into definition/required standards for "computer science literacy"
properties.Questions: CC standards Q-starting to think I should shift this up to D/D-
Common core math standards, has basic data interpretation/stats instruction
properties.Standards related to data science: In 2023, will require all high schoolers to take a year of a class involving "computer science literacy," which doesn't have to be comp sci (can literally be English if it includes the instruction), "literacy" not really defined
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: Decent instruction on data and technology (e.g. vizualization, presentation) in finance and business section
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: In math slightly, data analysis potentially in other classes given that standards haven't been defined
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: State currently developing comp sci standards, comp sci a priority
properties.Levels of instruction: mostly high school, but some computer education required throughout K-12
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 3 years of math including Alg I, something with geometry (does not specify it has to be only geo, so flexible), and a third which can be comp sci
AP comp sci is required to count as a math credit
properties.Availability/Access: Access limited now, but given recent legislation will increase
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 3-3.5 years required, 4 years recommended

properties.name: Indiana
properties.Updated Notes: No action since Commitments is visible. April not sure if you had any more recent conversations with them.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Indiana adopts statistics and data science standards similar to those in the Common Core. The state offers courses that cover some applied statistics and data analysis and has some data analysis units embedded in computer science coursework. However, most of the aforementioned offerings are electives and are not taken widely. We suggest making data science more prevalent in core math classes, and/or creating electives specifically regarding data science.
properties.Reasoning: Similar stats standards to common core; has additional course offerings that cover some stats applications; comp sci standards also cover some data analysis
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): Make data science more prevalent in core math classes; could create elective dedicated to data science
Post Alg II, Quantitative Reasoning class has standards invovling real-life data interpretation, collection, vizualization, though still somewhat theoretical but emphasizes tech use; also a Stats/Probability course

properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: little bit of data analytics in a few tech areas

Data science relevant courses seem to come after Alg II; comp sci does not appear to fall under math
properties.Availability/Access: Statewide standards; unclear if all district offer the more specialized courses after Alg II

properties.name: Massachusetts
properties.Updated Notes: Let's give them a B-. We talked to the State Math Lead and she is legit and introducing stuff. AS: Should they be this high up, they don't seem to have a super heavy focus on mandatory data science
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Massachusetts has impressively incorporated computational thinking into math, digital literacy, computer science and science frameworks, with an emphasis on modern technology tools. Data science courses are also approved in the state catalogue for optional high school math courses. We look forward to seeing more data science in the core math sequence and in earlier grades.

properties.Updated Notes: Let's talk about these two, cuz I think it is an interesting case. On one hand, NJ has better standards and requirement. But on the other, NH seems to actually have looser graduation requirements, which enable students to actually take classes in statistics/probabilities, data visualization, etc. How should we grade two?

properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Ohio has a detailed adaption of Common Core standards, which include data analysis standards. The Ohio Department of Education also created a pilot program to implement a high school Data Science Foundation's elective courses in high school mathematics, which includes thirteen K-12 school districts and eight Educational Service Centers (ESCs). However, data science content has yet to be required for all students, either embedded in other subjects or as its own course sequence. We suggest expanding the pilot.

properties.name: Virginia
properties.Updated Notes: April any updates here? VA Math Pathways was totally scrapped in Janurary with new governor. Idk if you have conversations with them recently. I don't have enough current context to assess.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Virginia's data science high school curriculum was approved by the state Board of Education in April. The state modernized its math currciulum. The new curriculum includes mandatory data analysis standards for the first two years of high school. The state also offers optional data science courses. The aforementioned pilot will be implemented July 2022. Modernized standards that incorporate statistical software for data analysis are being developed for K-8.
properties.Reasoning: Math initiative to modernize curriculum includes mandatory data analysis standards for 1st two years of high school, then options for data science courses; however, standards still being written
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): Write clear standards and implement them to guarentee A; also ensure data science reaches into middle school
properties.Questions: Talked to these people? What's the general opinion?
Has initiative to make high school math pathway more flexible; currently developing the curricula but wants to include data analysis, modeling, and more in form of modules--looks really good
properties.Standards related to data science: Current standards have stats in math and data analysis in comp sci
properties.CTE if it has relevant material (if noth: In marketing, business
properties.Separate class/curriculum or incorporate: Going to become separate classes and modules
properties.Taking Initiative/state level focus? (ha: Lot of initiative to make math curriculum better
properties.Grad Requirements (flexibility) in math,: 3 required math classes from approved list (including data analysis), comp sci can count as one of them
properties.Availability/Access: Comp sci widespread now, has funding; math changes coming 2023
properties.Public university entry requirements ma: doesn't list
properties.Other: May end up having fights over math program and accelerated courses

properties.name: Washington
properties.Updated Notes: April any updates here? I know they had ongoing work on the Algebra II stuff.
properties.Changes: No updates from Washington. Keep the original grade.
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Washington adopts Common Core math standards, which include very limited standards regarding data science. However, the state has also adopted technology standards required for middle and high school students, covering data visualization and modeling (CSTA). We suggest expanding data analysis in math, potentially making data science education mandatory.
properties.Reasoning: Usual cc standards; essentialy CSTA comp sci standards
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State-level plan; add on and expand standards in math, comp sci, other classes; make mandatory
Uses common core for math, section in high school on interpreting data, not very detailed/practical

properties.Public university entry requirements ma: 3 years math

properties.name: West Virginia
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): West Virginia adopts Common Core math standards with emphasis on using technology. The state also offers an optional Advanced Modeling class, which contains modules on statistics and working with data. However, we feel that the existing standards are still vague on data science competencies. We suggest clarfiying the existing standards and expanding data analysis in math.
properties.Reasoning: Usual cc standards with a bit more emphasis on technology use; optional Advanced Modeling class contains stats, working with data; vague mention of using data in comp sci
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State-level plan; more on data analysis in math, comp sci, other classes
properties.Questions: How much credit does optional course give you?
Good stats (w/ practical applications) instruction in Alg II; the Advanced Modeling option for fourth year math covers statistical analysis and modeling data w/ technology

properties.name: Wisconsin
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Wisconsin adopts Common Core math standards, which include very limited standards regarding data science. However, the state has good standards regarding data analysis in the comptuer science framework, although computer science is not yet widely taken by students. We suggest expanding data analysis in math, potentially making data science education mandatory.
properties.Reasoning: CC standards; good standards on data analysis for comp sci

properties.name: Wyoming
properties.Reasoning (Presentable): Wyoming has decent data science standards, especially in middle school years. The state also includes data analysis content in the computer science framework, but computer science is not yet widely taken by students. We suggest adding in more detailed standards focusing on data interpretation and visualization.
properties.Reasoning: Standards seem to cover more data analysis than cc, esp in middle school (seems built off cc standards); decent data analysis in comp sci
properties.How to improve (rough thoughts): State-level plan; could still add in some more standards; more focus on data interpretation, making comp sci more widespread
